page.title: 01The Butterstone Area
page.content: A delightful haven of tranquility arising out of the northern shores of Loches Craighoh, Lowes and Butterstone along a meandering stone wall lined road, pocked sited pasture occasional stone buildings. On the gentle slopes board leaved woods, leading to steeper ground coniferous forest and still higher grouse mors, with an abundence of wild flowers and wildlife. Red squirrel and red deer often seen roaming unhindered; in preference pheasants perch on five bar gates; rather than damp meadows by the road. From the moor a fast flowing burn tumbles and jumps over rocks into the loch. Butterstone despite mists attracts fly fishermen, who attempt to catch trout. The whole area reverting back to nature. There are no schools or churches, hardly any population, mostly making a living from tourism.
